title: Google’s experimental Windows app is better than Microsoft’s built-in search
content:
Google has so many products that it can be near-impossible to keep track. And yet, the company has rarely created desktop apps to go with those services. There are a handful, like Drive and Quick Share, but the company's flagship product is only now coming to the desktop. The new Google app for Windows is available now, allowing you to search the web, Google Drive, and even your local files.

The company stresses that the new app is experimental—it's limited to personal Google accounts, and you may encounter some bugs. The core functionality appears to be solid because it's not trying to do too much. After installation, you can press Alt+Space (or a shortcut of your choice) at any time to bring up a floating Google search bar. Just type your query, and the results page appears in a small window directly below the bar. It can also pull in select Knowledge Graph content, so you may not even have to type the whole query to get the information you need.

Microsoft's built-in Windows search functionality is notoriously crummy, and even in this experimental form, Google's Chrome OS-style search experience is better. It's fast, pulling up local files, Drive documents, and installed apps in a single interface. Both local files and Drive are optional, so you can use them only for search if you prefer. The app also includes Google Lens, which allows you to select anything on your PC's screen for image search or translation.

summary:
Key Takeaway:
Google has released an experimental Windows app that provides a more powerful and integrated search experience compared to Microsoft's built-in search functionality.

Why it Matters:
The new Google app offers a streamlined search interface that can access web results, local files, and Google Drive documents, potentially making it a more efficient and user-friendly alternative to the often-criticized Windows search.

Brief Context:
While Google has a vast array of products, the company has rarely created desktop apps to complement its services. The new experimental Windows app represents a notable exception, bringing Google's search capabilities directly to the desktop and challenging Microsoft's own search tools.

faq.question: What is the Google app for Windows?
faq.answer: nswer: The Google app for Windows is an experimental desktop app from Google that allows you to search the web, your Google Drive, and even local files on your Windows PC. It provides a Chrome OS-style search experience that is faster and more comprehensive than the built-in Windows search functionality.

faq.question: How does the Google app for Windows work?
faq.answer: nswer: The Google app for Windows lets you access a floating Google search bar by pressing Alt+Space (or a shortcut of your choice). You can then type in your query, and the results page will appear in a small window below the search bar. The app can also pull in relevant Knowledge Graph content, so you may not even need to type the full query to get the information you need.

faq.question: What features does the Google app for Windows have?
faq.answer: nswer: The key features of the Google app for Windows include: - Web search - Google Drive search - Local file search - Google Lens for image search and translation - Fast, comprehensive search results in a compact interface

faq.question: Is the Google app for Windows available to everyone?
faq.answer: nswer: No, the Google app for Windows is currently in an experimental phase and is only available to personal Google accounts. Google has stated that users may encounter some bugs as they test and refine the app.

faq.question: How does the Google app for Windows compare to Windows' built-in search?
faq.answer: nswer: According to the article, Microsoft's built-in Windows search functionality is "notoriously crummy," and even in its experimental form, the Google app provides a better search experience. The Google app is faster, pulls in results from the web, Google Drive, and local files in a single interface, making it more comprehensive than the standard Windows search.
